title: HSBC interim boss vows to speed up the bank's costly restructuring as profits tumble
text:
The boss of HSBC has pledged to speed up plans to 'remodel' the bank as profits fell by nearly a fifth amid weakness in Britain, Europe and the US.

Noel Quinn, who became interim chief executive in August after the bank announced the surprise departure of his predecessor John Flint, said profits held up well in Asia - its main market - despite unrest in Hong Kong.

'However, in some parts, performance was not acceptable, principally business activities within continental Europe, the non-ring-fenced bank in the UK, and the US,' he said.

Falling profits: HSBC said performance in Britain, Europe and the US was weak in Q3

'Our previous plans are no longer sufficient to improve performance for these businesses, given the softer outlook for revenue growth. We are therefore accelerating plans to remodel them, and move capital into higher growth and return opportunities.'

His comments follow recent reports claiming Quinn had plans to cut up to 10,000 jobs in a bid to slash costs and stamp his mark on the global banking group.

Profit before tax fell 18 per cent to $4.8billion (£3.7billion) in the third quarter of the year, with overall profits falling by 24 per cent to £3billion. Revenue fell 3 per cent 3 per cent to $13.4billion (£10.4billion).

Quinn said the bank would shift capital away from low-return businesses and further cut costs by simplifying HSBC's management structure.

But the restructuring is likely to result in 'significant charges' in its fourth quarter of this year, the bank said.

Return on tangible equity was down more than expected, at 6.4 per cent, with HSBC having to abandon its goal of achieving 11 per cent next year.

Shares in HSBC fell by 4 per cent to 592p in morning trading.

Richard Hunter at interactive investor, said: 'Not only are these numbers disappointing and light of expectations, but it seems that things will get worse before they get better.'

He added: 'Somewhat surprisingly, the performance in the Asian region from which HSBC derives the vast majority of its profits held up well, including a resilient performance (for the moment) from Hong Kong.'

HSBC chief executive Noel Quinn, who became interim chief executive in August after the bank announced the surprise departure of his predecessor John Flint

In Asia, overall pre-tax profit increased by 4 per cent to $4.7billion (£3.7billion), even though there was an additional $400million (£312million) charge to potential credit losses arising from the Hong Kong conflict.

'This is hardly an auspicious start for Noel Quinn, who as acting chief executive officer is auditioning for the role on a permanent basis,' said Russ Mould at AJ Bell.

'A renewed restructuring effort is in chain, with the aim of simplifying the business with further details expected at or around the full year results.

'However, along with the herculean task of bringing simplicity to a business as large and complex as HSBC, the bank has no control over factors such as a US-China trade war, Brexit and the escalating political tensions on its home turf in Hong Kong.'
